medium_description_en: Detects domestic abuse (intimate partner violence) in women and men in emergency department settings.

input_schema.name: one
input_schema.label_en: Has your partner threatened you with a weapon?

input_schema.name: two
input_schema.label_en: Has your partner beaten you so badly that you had to seek medical care?

input_schema.name: three
input_schema.label_en: Has your partner acted like they would like to kill you?

input_schema.name: four
input_schema.label_en: Has your partner had no respect for your feelings?

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use the Ongoing Violence Assessment Tool (OVAT) and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use the Ongoing Violence Assessment Tool (OVAT) and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

about.formula_en:
The OVAT screening result is determined according to the following points:

Variable

Points

Within the past month…

Has your partner threatened you with a weapon?

No

0

Yes

1

Has your partner beaten you so badly that you had to seek medical care?

No

0

Yes

1

Has your partner acted like they would like to kill you?

No

0

Yes

1

Has your partner had no respect for your feelings?

Never

1

Rarely

2

Occasionally

3

Frequently

4

Very frequently

5
about.more_info_en: A “yes” answer to any of the first three questions or an “occasionally”, “frequently”, or “very frequently” answer to the last question is considered a positive screening result.

Validation.text: Ernst AA, Weiss SJ, Cham E, Hall L, Nick TG. Detecting ongoing intimate partner violence in the emergency department using a simple 4-question screen: the OVAT. Violence Vict. 2004;19(3):375-384.

Feltner C, Wallace I, Berkman N, et al. Screening for intimate partner violence, elder abuse, and abuse of vulnerable adults: evidence report and systematic review for the US preventive services task force. JAMA. 2018;320(16):1688.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Weiss SJ, Ernst AA, Cham E, Nick TG. Development of a screen for ongoing intimate partner violence. Violence Vict. 2003;18(2):131-141.

creator_info.about_en: Steven Weiss, MS, MD FACP, FACEP, is a professor of medicine at University of New Mexico. He is presently the medical director of the Critical Care Transport Team for AAS. Dr. Weiss is the creator of both the CEDOCS, NEDOCS, and the more recent PEDOCS, and he is an avid researcher in Emergency Medicine, working towards ways to improve efficiency and efficacy of ED workflow.
